title: Unsatisfied HRTBs cause the compiler to suggest adding impossible bounds

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
Given the following code ([playground](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=stable&mode=debug&edition=2018&gist=978d9446191f7e77f30d41eea92ffcd0)):

```rust
trait Foo<'a> {}
impl<'a, T: 'a> Foo<'a> for T {}

trait Bar: for<'a> Foo<'a> {}
impl<T> Bar for T {}
```

The current output is:

```
error[E0311]: the parameter type `T` may not live long enough
 --> src/lib.rs:5:9
  |
5 | impl<T> Bar for T {}
  |      -  ^^^ ...so that the type `T` will meet its required lifetime bounds...
  |      |
  |      help: consider adding an explicit lifetime bound...: `T: 'a`
  |
note: ...that is required by this bound
 --> src/lib.rs:4:12
  |
4 | trait Bar: for<'a> Foo<'a> {}
  |            ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
```

Ideally there would be a way to say that `Bar` requires `Self` to implement `Foo<'a>` for any `'a` such that `Self: 'a`, however this is not possible. This case of the error can be fixed by additionally requiring `T: for<'a> Foo<'a>` when implementing `Bar`, however this will just shift the problem to whoever tries to use `Bar`. 

Anyway the help message is just wrong because `T` can't be restrained by `'a`, and trying `for<'a> T: 'a` just generates another identical error (which again suggest to bound `T` by `'a`). 

The suggestion also led me to write something like this ([playground](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=stable&mode=debug&edition=2018&gist=328332f623d0aa0a9d42c84a6f1fdeb6)):

```rust
trait Foo where for<'a> Self: 'a {}
```

On nightly and stable 1.54 (and older) the error message is pretty much the same the one already posted, the only difference with the other snippet is that I haven't found any workaround to make this compile.

Interestingly on stable 1.55 and beta it ICE, so it's technically a regression from stable to stable, however it's already fixed, so I don't think it's a big deal.
